reviews.text: It is a pretty steep climb up to La Torretta, and the B&B itself has a number of stairs. A small minibus runs periodically from near the tunnel to the railway station up to the parking lot above the town for those who don't want to climb.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2006, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Our family of four absolutely loved this quaint B&B. The owner and staff were so helpful and friendly and spoke good english. Our room was outstanding! The space was unbelievable by European standards and our children (10 & 12) even had their own room equipped with minibar and a television. A bottle of sparkling wine was left in the room for us to enjoy. The owner also stocks the bathroom with plenty of extras for you to use or take home (new sponge/looffah, incense, etc). The shower/tub was small, as some have mentioned in their reviews, but our family had quite a laugh cleaning up in this unique set up. We must remember that travelling comes with new experiences and if we want things exactly like our Canadian or American homes...we should stay there. The towels were small and thin, but they were of very high quality, quite absorbent and certainly nothing to complain about. They were so clean that they looked new and if they weren't, I think someone ironed them! Everything was lovingly displayed in our room as well. We had a huge balcony which my husband and I enjoyed some quiet time on during the evenings while the kids watched a bit of english tv. The view out to the sea was stunning. And, watching the locals from our balcony was very enjoyable. Early in the morning men and women were tending to their grape vines on the tiered land across from us, and late in the day people gathered in the streets sharing stories of the day. This little town was much less touristy that Vernazza and Monterossa and that was appealing to us especially during the evenings because it was much more peaceful. I was disappointed with Vernazza actually. We weren't even visiting during the busiest time of the year, and the garbage pails were overflowing with garbage and the streets were full of tourists. It was a pretty town, but I'm glad we stayed in Manarola. Monterossa was wonderful as it has a lovely beach. The kids played in the water and there are many great spots to stop for a bite to eat and a good Italian beer and just enjoy the view. It too was more touristy, but cleaner than Vernazza. When we first arrived in Manarola by we weren't certain where to find La Torretta, but just had to say the name to locals standing in their doorways and they would just say "up" and point where to go. The climb was not too bad, but we all had wheels on our suitcases and that made it quite bearable. There were no stairs to climb, just a windy street with pretty homes and shops lining it. When we left we had to leave quite early to catch the train and head up to Paris and couldn't wait until breakfast began, but the owner went out of his way and packed us a huge breakfast. It was enough food for the four of us to enjoy for breakfast AND lunch since he packed us so much food. The breakfasts were large, tasty, and quite artisically displayed. We will definitely come back and stay here. I'd like to stay longer (only spent two nights) next time and relax a bit. This was one of the highlights of our three week vacation in France and Italy.
reviews.title: Charming!

reviews.text: Our stay for 3 nights was very pleasant. The rooms, although on the small side were beautifully presented & had great views. Don't be put off by the walk up to the B & B - it was not far. If you are fit enough to walk the paths of the 5 villages - the walk back to La Torretta, after dinner at one of the fabulous restaurants, will be easy.

reviews.text: A forewarning to anyone making reservations with La Torreta. We were treated very poorly and want to let people know the risks involved with booking. We decided we wanted to stay at this hotel after reading reviews and inquired about reserving a room in August of 2006. We were informed by La Toretta that they would not accept reservations until December 1. We waited four months and then sent an email request from the U.S. the evening of November 30th knowing that it would arrive in Italy on December 1st. We were emailed back Friday evening (December 1st) and were told La Toretta had a room available and in order to reserve it, we should send them our credit card information. We emailed back that same evening and told La Torreta that we would definitely like to reserve the room and would send them via fax (rather than email) our credit card information on Monday, December 4th. We specifically asked if they would hold the room until they received our fax on Monday. La Toretta emailed us back and said that would it be fine to fax our credit card information on Monday. We faxed our credit card information to La Toretta first thing Monday morning and received an email response back later that day saying that the room was no longer available – they had given the room to someone else. We were shocked at the poor treatment we received when they had specifically told us they would hold the room until our fax arrived on Monday. It may be a terrific hotel with a terrific location, but their booking ethics are terrible.

Gabriele’s attentiveness to your every wish is reassuring while visiting this charming port city. Too, it is well located at the top near the church so traipsing in to the city where no cars are allowed with your luggage is tenable. So enchanted, we stayed an extra day.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My husband and two teenage sons spent three days in Cinque Terre in June. We stayed in Manarola at the La Torretta and it exceeded all our expectations. The lovely inn perched high above the seaside village was immaculate, unique, friendly, small, personal......I can't say enough. My only complaint was a chirping bird who gave us a wake up call every morning around 4:00 am - seems this little birdie was ready for breakfast early...but we always managed to drift back to sleep - in our wonderfully comfortable bed....We felt sooooo safe here and it was soooo quiet. Gabrielle is very nice and helfpul. The breakfast on the terrace provides plenty of carbs for the energy you'll need to hike the rocky cliffs joining the five villages....sorry- no meat or eggs with this breakfast - but always a fresh roll, yogurt and an assortment of other goodies - like nutella and honey.
reviews.title: Great views, quiet little village

likes.liked: — Beautiful location, good views of the ocean and terraced vineyards
likes.disliked: — Breakfast is a disappointment, even if the view is beautiful

reviews.text: If you are a family of 5, I recommend rooms 1,2,& 3 as they all adjoin - and best of all- the single room has a romeo and juliet balcony (just big enough for two chairs). The rooms were uniquely decorated (in a good way!) and our room even had a painted ceiling that made it so romantic and dreamy. On a clear day, the view of the golden sunsets defied words....
reviews.title: Beautiful place

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2007, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: If you want a simple, no fuss, low cost dinner, be sure to go to Discovola in Manarola for some take-out - tipical cuisine -foccacia bread pizza - the man who runs it is so nice and they have a great selection. We took our bag and sat on a park bench on the trail to Corniglia - overlooking the beautiful Mediteranean Sea--- it doesn't get any better than this!
